name: Lass

historicalClassification.note: Originally printed as a Trainer in Base Set. Would be classified as Supporter by modern rules due to affecting both players' hands significantly.

effect.text: You and your opponent show each other your hands, then shuffle all the Trainer cards from your hands into your decks.

tips: Best when you have fewer Trainers in hand than opponent
Devastating on turn 1 against setup decks
Play your important Trainers before using Lass
Only include in decks that can operate effectively without Trainers
Time usage for when you have board advantage and want to preserve it

competitiveHistory: Lass was a staple in aggressive Haymaker decks during the Base Set era. Playing Lass early could cripple opponents who relied on Trainers for setup, while aggressive decks with quick attackers could win before rebuilding their hand. It saw fringe competitive play primarily as a tech card in specific deck archetypes, particularly Pokemon Power-based decks that didn't rely on Trainers for their strategy.

rulings.ruling: Both players must reveal their entire hands to each other
All Trainer cards from both players' hands are shuffled into their respective decks
Pokemon and Energy cards remain in hand
Both players shuffle their decks after returning Trainer cards
The effect is mandatory; you cannot choose to keep Trainer cards in hand
If a player has no Trainer cards in hand, they still reveal their hand but shuffle nothing
Lass itself is not shuffled back (it's being played, not in hand)
The revealing happens first, then the shuffling
Both players see exactly which Trainer cards are being shuffled back
You cannot play other Trainer cards after revealing but before shuffling (Lass resolves completely)
